ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: A broad overview course that nonetheless familiarizes students in significant detail with the major debates and issues, as well as the historiography. Professor Bushkovitch makes sure to contextualize the topics under discussion, making the class relevant even for non-specialists.
This is a great seminar to learn about medieval and early modern Russian history and think about how it relates to Western Europe in this period.

You'll read a lot, but as introductions to this little-covered side of medieval history go, this one is thorough, captivatingly taught, and will bring you up to speed on both the history itself and the major historiographical trends. Go for it.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: I appreciated the challenge thiscourse presented in teaching me to question many of the assumptions that I often make, specializing in the modern history of the region. Professor Bushkovitch made sure to emphasize in the first meeting of this class that modern Russian history couldn't be grasped fully without a robust understanding of the pre-modern period, and this class made that point effectively on a regular basis.
